Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Revolutionary Design for a Continuous Adiabatic Demagnetization Refrigerator
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will demonstrate the feasibility of a novel Continuous Adiabatic Demagnetization Refrigerator (CADR) design by building and testing a prototype. This new technology has the potential to greatly reduce the cost of ultra-low temperature research. Currently, if a researcher needs to keep an experiment below 0.1K for more than a few days, there is only one viable technology: Dilution Refrigerators. These refrigerators rely on the very rare isotope He-3 (largely sourced from Tritium decay within the nuclear stockpile) and are quite expensive ($350,000 or more). The technology to be developed in Phase I promises to reduce this cost significantly by avoiding the complexity, size, infrastructure requirements, and He-3 reliance of Dilution Refrigerators. The envisioned CADR has the potential to help enable cost-effective quantum computing, the wide deployment of hyper-sensitive detectors for tracking nuclear material, the creation of quantum-information sensors critical to certain cryptographic schemes, in addition to other outcomes heretofore unknown.

The intellectual merit of this project is the creation of a revolutionary ultra-low temperature refrigerator. During this Phase I effort, a prototype refrigerator will be created which demonstrates the basic working principles of this new design. This prototype refrigerator will operate using a single stage of Gadolinium Gallium Garnet (GGG) as a refrigerant for continuously lifting heat from sub-Kelvin temperatures to a 3K pulse tube. This refrigerator will serve as a proof-of-concept for a two-stage refrigerator to be designed and tested in Phase II. The future two-stage refrigerator will use GGG to precool ferric ammonium alum (FAA) in order to reach 0.1 Kelvin and below. The research in this Phase I effort will feature an iterative process of subsystem characterization (heat switches, magnetic shielding, etc.), design, build and test. The Phase I effort is focused on answering the feasibility questions surrounding the engineering of this CADR while leaving 100 mK temperatures, multi-stage cooling, and deep analysis to Phase II. A successful proof of concept refrigerator to be demonstrated and characterized at the end of Phase I will move useful heat (goal of 0.5 milliwatts) from sub-Kelvin temperatures to a 3K pulse tube.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase I SBIR effort, "A Revolutionary Design for a Continuous Adiabatic Demagnetization Refrigerator" was focused on the physical proof of concept demonstration of a radical new design for CADR (Continuous Adiabatic Demagnetization Refrigerator) on the basis that the technology has the potential to drastically improve access to the sub-kelvin temperature regime. Beyond potential cost savings, the device does not use He-3, of which the long-term supply is uncertain.

The basic concept of this CADR was originally conceived approximately three years ago.  Preliminary modeling efforts and other work took place while we formulated a development and commercialization path. The Phase I efforts were directed towards this initial demonstration of a CADR. This CADR has only a single stage of cooling using GGG (Gadolinium Gallium Garnet) paramagnets as the refrigerant.  The engineering, building, and demonstration of such a new, complex device constituted a huge Phase I effort. Although we did not produce any useful cooling, we are proud of the amount of work accomplished in this project to design and build a first prototype in a short period of time.

The primary goal of this Phase I was the proof-of-concept demonstration of a refrigerator using this new concept. The motivation was to reduce the technical risk of a Phase II effort which would lead to a marketable product.

The effort went well past the initial schedule for several reasons. Before building the CADR some significant engineering was required. Although the complexity of detailed physics modeling and optimization was forgone, considerable engineering time was still required to devise something with a chance of working. Additionally some of the components in this CADR are quite specialized in composition and as such had considerable lead-times (3+months in some cases). Testing required the use of our in-house engineering cryostat which requires considerable planning, cool-down and operation time, making iteration and debug slow.  Extra testing and development was funded internally after Phase I funding was exhausted.

We did successfully create and test a CADR of this new design. However, rather than being a heat-pump, this device moved heat in too bi-directional a fashion to be useful, with the addition of expected loses, there was no useful continuous cooling. We had significant difficult in achieving adequate heat switching. However, other areas which were anticipated to be significant issues, such as the low-friction motion of large masses at 4K, did have some challenges but worked out better than anticipated.

While we are convinced that this design can be made to work as a refrigerator, we are increasingly concerned that the difficulty of getting the operating range down to .1 K may be so vast as to eliminate the design competitive advantage.  A short list of these difficulties include; the large mass of the magnet takes significant time (24-48 hours) to cool down to launch temperature (4K), the eddy currents generated in the support structure are significant.

Without a clear path to solving the technical and commercial difficulties at this time we have decided not submit a Phase II proposal. At this time we are unable to convince ourselves that this design, without significant modification, can be made as a profitable product. We did file a utility patent application and should further insight revive the concept we will be excited to re-visit this device.
